name: 1,3-bis[tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]propane
Reason: 1,3-Bis[tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]propane has a melting point that we will analyze by considering its structural components. The basic unit is propane, which has a melting point of 106.5 °C. The presence of two methylamino groups can increase the melting point due to the additional molecular weight and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +20 °C for each methylamino group. The tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino group introduces three hydroxyl functionalities, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +30 °C. The propane backbone itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigid structure and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +10 °C.
